intro: Isocoma villosa, commonly known as the hairy globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, as well as its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring. It typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in grasslands and scrub habitats. Isocoma villosa is adapted to arid environments and is considered a drought-tolerant species.
